awd_titl_txt: Criticality and Active Dynamics in Mechanical Detection by the Inner Ear
awd_abstract_narration:
The auditory (hearing) and vestibular (balance) systems provide us with rich information about the world around us. To achieve this, these sensory systems perform remarkable mechanical detection, responding to very small movements in the hair cells of the inner ear. This sensitivity has to be achieved even in a noisy environment in order to allow individuals to distinguish sounds that they want to hear and interpret from background noise.  While the fundamental process of hearing is known, the processes that support acuity of hearing (being able to clearly detect the important sounds) are not well understood.  This project will look at the fundamental mechanics and physics of the response of hair cells in order to better understand the dynamics of the hearing process.  Beyond advancing understanding of this important physiological process, the knowledge gained from the research may also inform the development of sensor systems that mimic the process of the ear.  The award will enable the inclusion of undergraduate researchers, recruited through programs that broaden the participation of students from under-represented minorities. The laboratory will also include high school students in the research project, focusing on encouraging women to pursue studies in this field.

This project has two guiding hypotheses.  First, that the coupling between hair cells changes the dynamics of the system, poising it closer to criticality.  Second, that the presence of weak chaos in the coupled system enhances its sensitivity.  In order to investigate thse hypotheses, this project will use in vitro preparations of the bullfrog sacculus to assess how coupled systems of hair bundles achieve their detection. Specifically, the research will look for signatures of criticality, which would be a regime that leads to a highly sensitive response and a broad range of power-law behavior. The project will also explore the role of chaotic dynamics in the fully coupled system in order to determine how chaoticity in individual bundles is modified by the coupling, as well as how it affects the performance of the full system. To elucidate the role of these dynamic regimes, the project will use preparations that incorporate different coupling conditions. For one set of experiments, it will use hybrid preparations, in which different numbers of hair bundles will be connected to build arrays of different sizes. For another set of experiments, semi-intact systems will be used, which preserve the innate, overlying membrane. The researcher hypothesizes that the system is poised near criticality, on the weakly oscillatory side, and that the critical oscillations exhibit chaotic dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Vestibular and auditory systems present us with remarkable examples of mechanosensation in biology. Hair cells of the inner ear display detection abilities that reach the nanometer scale despite being immersed in a noisy and dissipative fluid environment. Under in vivo conditions, the individual cells are typically coupled to each other by overlying structures. In this set of projects, we explored the role of this coupling on the dynamics of the system, using a combination of theoretical and experimental approaches. Our experiments were performed on in vitro preparations of the bullfrog sacculus. We developed hybrid preparations, with various artificial membranes imposing different degrees of coupling on live and functional hair cells. The preparation allowed us to vary the extent of coupling between individual active elements and thus observe its impact on the overall dynamics of the system. The experiments revealed that coupling can leads to a rich set of dynamical states that can arise in the full system. Specifically, we observed that chaotic dynamics, shown to be present in individual hair bundles, enhance their ability to synchronize to each other when they are coupled. As a result, the coupled system showed significant improvement in the system’s ability to detect weak signals. We found that this synchronization persisted even for a large frequency dispersion, mimicking certain biological epithelia. Our numerical models reproduced the experimental data and demonstrated that the synchronization leads to an enhanced sensitivity. Further, upon expanding the number of coupled elements, we observed chimera states and frequency clustering. These are dynamical states known in mathematical literature to occur near the onset of synchronization. We demonstrated the existence of these states and reproduced them with theoretical models, which showed that they can be applied to explain phenomena observed in the auditory system. We propose that the occurrence synchronized and partially synchronized states may serve to explain the remarkable detection abilities displayed by the auditory and vestibular systems. This project has provided a number of educational opportunities, by enabling the group to include graduate, undergraduate, and high school students of diverse backgrounds into the laboratory. Thus, it has provided means of training young scientists at this rich interface between biological and physical sciences.
